Intro to Vector Bundles on Manifolds

1. Introduction

In this note we aim to provide a more formal introduction to the theory of vector bundles on smooth manifolds following Chapter 10 in Lee's Smooth Manifolds[1]. This work generalizes the theory of the tangent bundle on manifolds.

2. Vector Bundles

Consider a topological space throughout.

Vector Bundle

A real vector bundle of rank over is a topological space together with a surjective continuous map satisfying the following conditions:

  1. For each , the fiber over is endowed with the structure of a -dimensional vector space.
  2. For each , there exists a neighborhood of in and a homeomorphism , called a local trivialization of over , satisfying
    1. (i.e. is a bundle map over )
    2. For each , the restriction is an isomorphism of vector spaces.

The space is called the total space of the bundle, is called its base, and is its projection.

Note that a real vector bundle is precisely a locally trivial fibration (c.f. Basics of Fiber Bundles and Principal BundlesBasics of Fiber Bundles and Principal Bundles) with fiber , and with a choice of atlas such that the transition functions are linear isomorphisms on the fibers.

If and are smooth manifolds with or without boundary, is a smooth map, and the local trivializations can be chosen to be diffeomorphisms, then is called a smooth vector bundle and any local trivialization that is a diffeomorphism is called a smooth local trivialization.

We usually refer to rank-1 vector bundles as (real) line bundles. If we replace with above, and require all vector spaces to be -vector spaces, we obtain the notion of a complex vector bundle. In this note we will restrict to considering real vector bundles.

Smooth Vector Bundle Maps are Submersions

***

If there exists a global trivialization of a vector bundle , we will say that is a trivial bundle. If is a smooth bundle admitting a smooth global trivialization, we say that the bundle is smoothly trivial.

For the remainder of the note we will primary be restricting to smooth bundles and smooth trivializations.

Product Bundle

If , then , the projection, is naturally a rank -real vector bundle called the product bundle, and by construction is trivial. If is a smooth manifold with or without boundary, then is smoothly trivial.

3. Local and Global Sections of a Vector Bundle

Let be a vector bundle throughout. A local section of is a lift of an open inclusion . We will refer to such a section as rough if it is only a section on the level of set functions (i.e. not necessarily smooth or even continuous).

The support of a section is defined as the closure of the set .

3.1. Local and Global Frames

As with the special case of the tangent bundle, we can talk about local and global frames of vector bundles more generally.

Linearly Independent and Spanning Sections

A -tuple of local sections of a vector bundle over (open) is said to be linearly independent if is linearly independent in for all . Similarly, they span if their values span for each .

A local frame for over is an ordered -tuple of linearly independent local sections over that span . If this is called a global frame.

A smooth vector bundle is smoothly trivial if and only if it admits a smooth global frame.

When the base for the bundles are the same, often we restrict to the notion of a bundle homomorphism over which is a map in the slice category .

Bijective Smooth Bundle Homomorphisms are Isomorphisms

Let and be smooth vector bundles. If is a bijective smooth bundle homomorphism over , then is a smooth bundle isomorphism.

Proof.
It suffices by Smooth Maps and Smooth Partitions of Unity > ^9a4fc0Smooth Maps and Smooth Partitions of Unity > ^9a4fc0 to show that has constant rank. For this we can take a common local trivialization, in which induces a bundle map which is identity in the first variable and a multiplication by a smooth transition matrix function in the second variable. The inverse of this map is given by using matrix inversion on this transition matrix function, and hence is smooth. Thus, is a local diffeomorphism with inverse being linear on fibers, and hence a bundle homomorphism.
***

Note that if is a smooth map, the global differential is a smooth bundle homomorphism covering . Additionally, pullback as in Intro to Vector Bundles on Manifolds > ^77fbc1Intro to Vector Bundles on Manifolds > ^77fbc1 gives a vector bundle homomorphism.

4.2. Fiber Bundle

Fiber Bundle

Let and be topological spaces. A fiber bundle over with model fiber is a topological space together with a surjective continuous map with the property that for each , there exists a neighborhood of in and a homeomorphism over , called a local trivialization of over .

If and are smooth manifolds, is a smooth map, and the local trivializations can be chosen to be diffeomorphisms, then this is the definition of a smooth fiber bundle. (c.f. Basics of Fiber Bundles and Principal BundlesBasics of Fiber Bundles and Principal Bundles for more details)

5. The Cotangent Bundle

In this section we introduce the cotangent bundle on a smooth manifold, which is a vector bundle that collects tangent covectors at points of the manifold, which correspond to linear functionals on the tangent space at that appropriate point. These constructions will allow us to obtain a coordinate-independent analogue of the gradient construction for smooth real-valued functions.

Covector fields will then provide a natural foundation for the beginning of the study of integrals on manifolds, starting with line integrals.

Covector
